content.description:
Start on the obvious bulb near arete, climb straight to top on good holds. 

  A doable, but possibly heady route for the new climber.
content.location: To the right of Leaning Rock

content.description: An excellent highball though a tad spooky. Climb arete and just to the left to the top.  #16 JJ's old topo.
content.location: Back bone

content.description: Start sitting below Nameless and climb into Sandstone Violence.  This climbs through the entirety of the proud wall and the movement is fantastic.  Similar in difficulty and style to the Keymaker at Devil's Lake, though maybe a touch harder.
content.protection: I had 4 pads.  A couple big ones won't hurt.

content.description: Start out on good holds and work your up to better ones on corner to top.  #17 JJ's old topo.

Start at some small holds and get up to the curved jug.  Work your way into the corner to finish up.  You can also start over on the ear lobe hold and work into the start for a bit more difficulty.  #13 JJ's old topo.
content.location: Back bone

content.description: sit-start and move up through side pulls in to big undercling, hike your feet and move to horn.
content.location: on the side of the battle of the bulge

content.description: Start in notch with small roof. Work up some small holds tending left to jugs. Straight up to top.  #12 JJ's old topo.
content.location: Back Bone

content.description: Nice warm-up with pinches, pockets, edges, and jugs.  #12a JJ's old topo.
content.location: Right behind #11 Leaning Rock and to the right of #12.  If you look at the top, there should be a huge tree that you can crawl under when you top out.

content.description: Start with a high right and move to big side pull for left hand and move up and out left to sloppy ramp.  climb get a bit scary up top due to marginal holds.   Tread softly on the right hand side pull it might come off some day soon.
content.location: back bone left on nameless arete. start on hold two feet left of crack with right hand

content.description: Work your way up to the ledge with well-placed and obvious hands. Mantle and top out.
content.location: Just right of the crack (Layback Crack Attack) to the right of the tree.

content.description: Climb tall arete using crack out left.  Top-out can be tricky.
content.location: 2nd arete to the right of Wrights Arete.

content.description: Decent problem if you ignore the little ledge and the boulders below you.  Move up slabby face on decent holds and high feet.
content.location: Face right of Take My Picture.

content.description: The bottom has nice jugs/edges to get to the middle of the problem staying on the left side to center but once past the overhang the small tiny crimps, edges, and pinches come out to play.  Straight up a little to the right.
content.protection: None.  2 spotters and 2+ pads you will need
content.location: On the Bone Ridge between problems #15 and #16 there is a huge boulder problem that has no info on it.  There is a broken tree behind it big tall face on corner

content.description:
In many ways THE line on Backbone Ridge if not the whole park. This slightly overhanging line is filled with unique moves and an all out toss to a jug at 3/4 height. Start out in the middle of the block on a good sidepull. Work straight up past hard holds and an almost ghostlike crimp up high to the horizontal. Top out through a niche at the top. A very tall, proud line.

#14 JJ's old topo.
content.location: Backbone

content.description: Super sharp crimping the whole way, youll want good finger pads , or a zen like mind state to do this one...
content.location: The Face just opposite of Mr. Clean. About 3 feet right of the corner. Heads straight up.

content.description: Stand start on right low crimp and high left pinch/sidepull. The meat of the route comes next with intricate footwork leading you into a very slopey right leaning rail. Continue to apex of rail and top out directly. (hint: the lip right above you is bomber)
content.location: Between battle of the bulge and trail crew. (Its sqeezed in there, but suprisingly isnt an eliminate)

content.description: Start as for Sandstone Violence, traverse left to Nameless Arete.  Adds a fun few moves and hard to go wrong finishing on Nameless.  Maybe easier for the tall.
All large edges, a big crack and big foot holds make this a good warm up.
content.location: Left of Picasso Left.  when coming down path will be on your left.  Easy climb to warm up.

content.description: Start out on arete, and work to two pockets.  Straight up corner to the top.  #20 JJ's old topo.
content.location: Back Bone

content.description: Ascend the narrow pillar on crimps and slopes straight to the top. This climbs surprisingly well considering its width...
content.location: Very narrow pillar right between Picasso chimney and #19 (VO crack)

content.description: Start out on a good left crimp and right crimp sidepull.  Go up to the hollow jugs and then work to the right corner.  Climb to top just left of corner.  #22 JJ's old topo.
content.location: Back bone

content.description: Start out with hands on either side of the arete.  Get the pocket jug with the right and work up arete using side pull crimps on left and larger holds on right.  Finish with a jam in the finger crack at the top.  Very exciting.  #21 JJ's old topo.
content.location: Back bone left side

content.description: Climb crack- some very nice jams in there...  #19 JJ's old topo.
content.location: Left side back bone

content.description: Climb slab route just left of Nameless Arete.  Fun warm-up.
content.protection: Pads and spotters; the top is committing.
content.location: Backbone- just left of Nameless Arete.

content.description: Start sitting and climb Nameless.  A couple holds on the right face may just be important.  This adds a few interesting moves to an already awesome climb.

This is a stand out classic.  Climb the arete on the right side with powerful gut tension core popping moves will keep you moving until you reach the first of two crimps on the arete up high.  One more set of moves and it is nearly all over...  #15 JJ's old topo.
content.location: Back bone

content.description: Start with undercling and climb flake and face to jug topout.
content.location: Right of Sandstone Violence about 30ft.

content.description: Start with right hand on small nob, left hand on small crimp, work your way up crimpy face into sidepulls up to a great jug rest, hike your feet and go for large ledge out left.  Topout.
content.location: Left around corner from Nameless Arete.  Climb starts just right of tall cracks in face right of Trail Crew.

content.description: This route starts in the middle of the face and works its way up the left arete. The crux is a right hand throw to the bad arete, after securing a left hand crimp on the arete. Bringing the feet up over the lip of the roof may also be a comittment crux for some.
content.location: About 25 feet past nameless arete. A 5 foot tall slab/face capped with a 1.5 foot horizontal roof, which then has a slightly concave/vertical 10 foot face atop it. Also about 5 feet right of a large tree that hugs the cliff.

content.description: You can start down and on the right low, or on the left.  Hit the arete and up and over.  #11 JJ's old topo.
content.location: Back Bone

content.description: A fun angled crack climb with plenty of good hands and feet.
content.location: Just right of the tree right of Sandstone Violence. Take the crack all the way to the top.

content.description: Climb Finger crack to top and either exit left or move up face to top out.
content.location: In first warm up area on back side of backbone.

content.description: climb up left arete and top out.  Super fun for any one in the group that needs confidence improving lines.
content.location: This is the first rock on the right trail when heading to main line of climbs at back bone.  Take trail then go back on trail towards rock.

content.description: Maybe this is Wrights Arete, but there is a direct line that avoids using the arete and staying on the face.  A good fun highball none the less.
content.location: Left face of Wrights Arete.

content.description: Starts on right arete and moves up and left using sloper rail and crimps
content.location: Starting on the arete just Left of route #12 in the JJs topo. Also a few feet right of Mr. Clean.

content.description:
Start at a large,Â right facing sidepull. Layback up to some decent holds and move up to the lonely sidepull. 

Up to the top. #18 JJ's old topo.
content.location: Backbone

climbs.name: Don't Commit! The Footchip You Are On Is Broken!

content.description: Starts the same as Slabracadabra, then straight up the face, crux at the top. Right face is off.
content.location: Face right of Take My Picture.

content.description: Start by using both cracks. Deep fingers get you into the climb. Climb past wobbly block on right. The right crack becomes to small to get fingers in and the left crack stops for a bit. Layback the small arete on the right crack and move up. Reachy moves to topout. The crux is in your mind. This thing gets scary.
content.location: the 2 cracks left of "Midwest Hardcore"

content.description: Start same as for Left Out, but move up the right arete staying and finishing on the face. After the roof there is a great sidepull around the right corner and up, after grabing this with right hand throw high and left for small crimp on the face. Crux is hitting the next sloper and keeping your feet from dangling.
content.location: About 25 feet past nameless arete. A 5 foot tall slab/face capped with a 1.5 foot horizontal roof, which then has a slightly concave/vertical 10 foot face atop it. Also about 5 feet right of a large tree that hugs the cliff.

content.description: Sit start on OK right hand and small left crimp with good right foot, move up and right to slot one more move to the top. Fun hard sit start to nice mantel top out. Full Rib Mt style problem.
content.location: boulders right behind Sand Stone Violence.

content.description: Climb offwidth chimney just right of the Picasso lines.
content.protection: Pads and helps to wear pants.
content.location: Far end of Group B cliff band.

content.description: Sit Start under the left side of the roof on large jug, move out the bulge, onto the face and directly up the arete using sidepulls on either side. Crux comes when trying to get fingers into the small vertical crack on the right hand face.
content.location: 15 feet past nameless arete there is another arete that doesnt touch the ground

content.description: Slightly contrived, maybe reachy, but there are fun moves. Vince has been trying to work the face directly, this line strays slightly right.
content.location: Face to the right of "Forgotten Finger Crack". Use a right crimp around the corner, left hand in a vertical seam halfway up, match right hand and get into the horizontal seam on two decent holds. Right of the vertical seam is off.

content.description: Climb up on good edges
content.location: On the wall to the right of the warm-up problem 12a on the backbone

content.description:
The western side of the ridge proper.  Great afternoon and evening sun.  The rock is generally a bit better on this side.  Good landings for the most part, but some problems are quite tall.  Be careful! 

  I have left the numbers on the original problems posted by JJ Schlick, from his topo.
